result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

10:05 AM Prosecuting attorney Craig Lambert in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Matthew C Brogan not in court.

records.addlTxt: Order for Competency Examination by Department of Health Services
Motion and Order to Withdraw as Counsel

8:28 AM Defendant Matthew C Brogan appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Joseph Edward Long JD in court for Matthew C Brogan.  Attorney Nathan T. Oswald in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Officer Johnson is sworn in and testifies. Testifies to being an Officer with the Wood County Sheriff's Department. Testifies to being dispatched to a home due to the defendant being verbally abusive. Testifies to speaking with MJB. Testifies to MJB statements of what happened. Testifies to MJB not giving the defendant permission to cause a disturbance. Testifies to speaking with the defendant. Witness identifies the defendant in court, court recognizes. 
Attorney Long cross examines the witness. 
Attorney Oswald questions the witness. Testifies to the defendants girlfriend and son having to leave the residence because of the disturbance.

Court takes judicial notice of prior cases.

Defendant is sworn in and testifies. Attorney Long questions the defendant.
Defendant testifies to being at the residence of MJB. Testifies to not yelling or causing a disturbance. Testifies to not being asked to leave. Testifies to not being a threat to anyone. 
Attorney Oswald questions the defendant. Testifies to thinking we were speaking about a different incident. Testifies to an argument.

Court finds probable cause to believe a felony was committed and the defendant committed it. 

Bond is continued.
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on June 17, 2022 at 08:30 am.
No contact w/victim or their residence

1:58 PM Prosecuting attorney Daniel McGrath in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Matthew C Brogan appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Joseph Edward Long JD in court for Matthew C Brogan. 
Attorney Long informs the court that a competency evaluation was ordered in this case. Court cancels warrant and reinstates previous bond.
Body Only
Body Only
